description: From Middle English hole (“healthy, unhurt, whole”), from Old English hāl (“healthy, safe”), from Proto-West Germanic *hail, from Proto-Germanic *hailaz (“whole, safe, sound”), from Proto-Indo-European *kóylos (“healthy, whole”).
The spelling with wh-, introduced in the 15th century, was for disambiguation with hole, and was absent in Scots.

adjectives.description: whole (comparative wholer or more whole, superlative wholest or most whole)

examples: I brought a whole lot of balloons for the party.   She ate a whole bunch of french fries.
Synonyms: hale, well; see also Thesaurus:healthy
He is of whole mind, but the same cannot be said about his physical state.

entries.meaning: (of food) From which none of its constituents has been removed.

adverbs.description: whole (comparative more whole, superlative most whole)

entries.meaning: Something complete, without any parts missing.
examples: Synonyms: entireness, totality; see also Thesaurus:entirety
This variety of fascinating details didn't fall together into an enjoyable, coherent whole.
